title: Economic impact of COVID-19 on digital infrastructure
content:
In this issue

As we look ahead towards global recovery, it will be important for governments, digital policy-makers and regulators, and the tech sector to ensure that further actions are based on solid evidence.  In this ITU report, leading digital economy experts have put their collective heads together in an attempt to get a clearer look at the economic impact of COVID-19 on the world’s digital infrastructure – not just a rear-view mirror look, but a far-sighted view from the driver’s seat, too.

title: 2020 UN Activities on Artificial Intelligence
content:
In this issue

At a time when the coronavirus crisis is disrupting progress toward the achievement of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), the projects being developed by the UN Agencies serve as a reminder that AI and other digital technologies can reverse this trend and accelerate progress in areas as fundamental to our future as climate change, poverty, energy, education, biodiversity, and health. It also makes clear that UN agencies will not rest until everyone, everywhere is connected and can benefit from these technologies.

title: The State of Broadband 2020: Tackling digital inequalities – A decade for action
content:
In this issue

The world in 2020 is in a state of flux. While much progress has been made globally over the past ten years in expanding access to, and adoption of, broadband infrastructure and services, significant challenges remain in tackling digital inequalities, addressing the current widespread impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, and in accelerating efforts towards achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) by 2030.
The broadband ecosystem has the opportunity to play a positive role in society and economies, strengthening infrastructure, institutions, and systems that not only address the current challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic, but also prepare the world for future disasters.

title: SDG Digital Investment Framework – A whole-of-Government Approach to Investing in Digital Technologies to Achieve the SDGs
content:
In this issue

The United Nations is not on track to achieve its Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) by 2030. Despite billions of dollars in investment, lack of coordination is hampering progress toward these goals, but progress can be accelerated. SDG Digital Investment Framework encourages a whole-of-government approach to digital investments so that governments can address key strategic questions while focusing on effective and scalable tech-based solutions toward sustainable development. By deploying technology cross-functionally across the agriculture, education and healthcare sectors, The International Telecommunication Union (ITU) and Digital Impact Alliance (DIAL) point to use cases, workflows and building blocks that can impact reaching the SDGs more effectively and efficiently.

title: Connecting Humanity
content:
In this issue

Nearly half the global population aged 10 years and over – equating to some three billion people – has never used the Internet. Many of the unconnected live in rural and remote areas, where connectivity remains a challenge. A disproportionate number are women, particularly in Africa and South Asia, where the digital gender divide is particularly marked. And of course most are poor, lack basic literacy and, with only limited digital exposure, see little value in getting online.
With just ten years remaining to meet the SDGs, this timely new report asks: What will it take to connect the world? How much investment is needed, where are the global ‘pain points’, and how can we mobilize the unprecedented levels of financing needed to extend networks to unserved communities?

title: ITU News Magazine – Tech v COVID-19: Managing the crisis
content:
In this issue

Welcome to ITU News Magazine – your source for insight on key ITU events and initiatives, as well as global information and communication technology (ICT) trends.

Read this issue for:

– The vital role of digital technologies in this time of crisis
– How ICTs are being leveraged in response to the COVID-19 pandemic
– How ITU and partners are helping to build back better.
Browse other editions of the ITU News Magazine here.

title: Guide to develop a TELECOM-ICT contingency plan for a pandemic response
content:
In this issue

The Covid-19 crisis has demonstrated the essential role of connectivity worldwide and the importance of having telecommunications and ICT in place for coordination mechanisms to respond to it. The response has demonstrated the strategic importance of a robust, resilient, and secure telecommunications/ICT infrastructure to social welfare and the global economy. This document presents a set of proposals for effective telecommunications/ICT contingency planning and response.

title: Manual for Measuring ICT Access and Use by Households and Individuals 2020
content:
In this issue

The aim of this Manual is to support countries in their efforts to collect and disseminate ICT statistics, based on internationally agreed definitions and standards. It is designed as a practical tool to guide countries in their ICT data production, serving as a basic reference when preparing, designing and implementing ICT household surveys. To assist our members and partners make best use of it, ITU is also developing complementary training material.

title: Digital Financial Services Consumer Competency Framework 2020
content:
In this issue

DFS consumers must be able to use the new technologies for financial transactions in a secure manner and must also have the necessary competences to understand the risks and make informed decisions when using digital financial services. This document identifies the knowledge, skills and attitudes consumers need to participate actively, safely and have trust in the digital financial services ecosystem.

title: Security testing for USSD- and STK-based digital financial services applications
content:
In this issue

Digital Financial Services providers have increasingly utilized Unstructured Supplementary Service Data (USSD) and Sim Tool Kit channels to enhance the growth and adoption of Digital Financial Services (DFS), primarily in the developing world. It is estimated that over 90 per cent of mobile money transactions in Africa are driven by USSD. This document proposes best practices for DFS providers, Mobile Network Operators, and other users of these environments.

title: Women, ICT and emergency telecommunications: opportunities and constraints
content:
In this issue

In the wake of a disaster, women are more vulnerable and more likely to die than men. Yet how often are their needs specifically addressed in work to prepare for, respond to and recover from disasters, even though doing so could unlock many opportunities and unblock many constraints?

title: Working practices using objective metrics for evaluation of video coding efficiency experiments
content:
In this issue

In this ITU-T Technical Paper you will find a description of Bjøntegaard Delta rate (BD-rate) measurement practices for video coding experiments,  a concept-level overview of recent practices, references to technical papers that describe further details, comments on why some of the choices were made and situations where caution must be taken when interpreting the results.

title: Analysis and related solutions for full duplex interference
content:
In this issue

This report describes several primary interferences that will impact the in-band full-duplex cable modem (CM) performance, and also provides interference mitigation solutions.

title: Integrated broadcast-broadband digital TV application cooperated with server for functional extension including functions of digital TV reception and processing
content:
In this issue

An ITU technical paper that describes an integrated broadcast-broadband (IBB) digital television (TV) application that cooperates with the server for functional extension, including functions of digital TV reception and processing.

title: Network 2030 – Architecture Framework
content:
In this issue

This technical specification describes architectural principles and overall architecture for public networks in the year 2030 and beyond It also elaborates on the details of access/edge architecture, routing and addressing, data path security, quality of service (QoS), burst switching, network slicing, Multi-access Edge Computing (MEC) federation, network management for Network 2030 and the impact of quantum computing.

title: Be He@lthy, Be Mobile – Handbook on How to Implement Mhypertension
content:
In this issue

The Be He@lthy, Be Mobile initiative uses basic technologies common in most mobile phones to provide guidance to policy-makers and implementers of national/large-scale mHealth programmes for noncommunicable diseases. This handbook describes how an mHypertension programme can be used to supplement and augment existing national hypertension control programmes, and illustrates the steps required for successful implementation.

title: Radiocommunications and climate change
content:
In this issue

Climate change and growing exploitation of the Earth’s natural resources is leading to a range of environmental problems that require international action. If humanity is going to respond effectively, many of the solutions will be informed by global monitoring of the environment, including the use of space assets. Satellite data is today an indispensable input for weather prediction models and forecast systems used to produce safety warnings and other information in support of public and private decision-making.

title: COP Online safety activity book – Work with Sango
content:
In this issue

The storybook presents six scenarios with questions to think about and answer to learn about rights and safety online. Each scenario provides your child with a question and two possible answers. Reading the book with your child creates an opportunity to talk with them about being online.

title: U4SSC – Accelerating city transformation using frontier technologies
content:
In this issue

Frontier technologies provide cities with an innovatory opportunity to expedite their transformation to unique cyber-physical systems, capitalising on data exchange among heterogeneous agents, while encapsulating the concepts of “smartness” and “sustainability” in their operations. To this end, the transformative potential of frontier technologies is exemplified in their ability to reshape the way cities provide services and meet citizens’ needs.

title: Network 2030 – Additional representative use cases and key network requirements for Network 2030
content:
In this issue

Towards the year of 2030 and beyond, many novel applications are expected to emerge as others mature, leading to increasingly intertwined human and machine communications. New applications often trigger new services and introduce challenging requirements that demand the continuous evolution of networking technologies. Thus, the inherent capabilities of interconnected networks and the running principles therein need to be enhanced, or even replaced, as requirements unfold.

title: Status of National Child Online Protection Ecosystems in South Eastern Europe
content:
In this issue

Given the great diversity and complexity of actors, technologies and agencies, as well as opportunities and threats, understanding the complexities of child online protection should be an imperative for all stakeholders. The ITU COP guidelines reports are a useful tool in the design and implementation of a national child online protection strategy.

title: Network 2030 – Terms and Definitions for Network 2030
content:
In this issue

This technical specification represents a glossary of terms helping to understand the Network 2030 use cases, requirements, challenges, and potential operation.

title: Network 2030 – Gap analysis of Network 2030 new services, capabilities and use cases
content:
In this issue

This Technical Report presents the current work on network and communication services that has been carried out by different standards development organizations (SDOs) with respect to the Network 2030 services, capabilities, and representative use cases.

Based on these inputs, the report identifies gaps, namely issues and technologies that are not currently addressed, and will be required for the support of new use cases and the network infrastructure of 2030 and beyond.

The report uses Network 2030 services and use case cluster reports as an input for the Network 2030 related requirements.

title: Building Smart Villages: A Blueprint – as Piloted in Niger
content:
In this issue

A blueprint for a locally led, integrated and holistic approach to providing access to digital services to all citizens of rural communities, with the integration of digital technologies serving as a crucial enabler of equitable, qualitative and efficient delivery of SDG-related services for all.

title: ITU Guidelines for national emergency telecommunication plans
content:
In this issue

An invaluable aid to increase preparedness of the emergency communications sector for when disasters strike. This guide outlines the key steps and phases of planning, designing, conducting and following up of an emergency simulation exercise, with templates, checklists and guidance to assist in running a simulation, and other resource materials.

title: Security considerations for quantum key distribution networks
content:
In this issue

Quantum computing and secure quantum communications will have profound impact on ICT networks. Quantum key distribution (QKD) and Post-quantum cryptography (PQC) are pillars of quantum-safe cryptography. This Technical Report focuses on QKD technologies and the need to develop a QKD framework that meets the requirements of telecom networks.

title: ITU News Magazine – AI for Good: Global impact
content:
In this issue

Welcome to ITU News Magazine – your source for insight on key ITU events and initiatives, as well as global information and communication technology (ICT) trends.

Read this issue for:
– The 2020 AI for Good Global Summit – all year, always online, featuring weekly programming.
– Breakthrough and solutions tracks’ to explore how AI can be harnessed to improve lives
– Key insights from a diverse range of AI thought leaders participating in the Summit.

Browse other editions of the ITU News Magazine here.

title: Identify call location for emergency service
content:
In this issue

A major challenge for emergency services is determining the accurate location of the emergency, particularly in instances when callers are unable to verbally describe their location due to stress, injury, language or simple unfamiliarity with an area. This Technical Report will examine network-based, handset-based and/or hybrid solution protocols that are instrumental in the identification of call location.

title: Digital Innovation Profile – Montenegro
content:
In this issue

Digital innovation profiles offer a rapid and straightforward means of analysing and optimizing your ICT ecosystem. This analysis helps navigate through Montenegro’s fast-moving ICT/ telecommunication landscape with a view to building a competitive, sustainable, ICT-enabled economy.

title: ITU Journal (ICT Discoveries) – Special issue on The future of video and immersive media
content:
In this issue

Our multimedia-rich communications experience is built on international standards that give innovators the confidence to invest in new applications and services. These standards are at play in almost all video we view, over any medium. Among all the types of data that travel through the internet and mobile networks everyday, video represents by far the largest portion of traffic – about 80% by some estimates, and growing exponentially. In this special issue we discuss insights into the state of the art in multimedia and consider emerging applications and new possibilities, with a deeper look from the perspectives of standards, technology, industry and societal impact throughout carefully selected collection of papers covering a wide range of timely topics.

title: COP Online with Sango
content:
In this issue

The storybook presents six scenarios with questions to think about and answer to learn about rights and safety online. Each scenario provides your child with a question and two possible answers. Reading the book with your child creates an opportunity to talk with them about being online.

title: ITU-R Radiocommunication Study Groups
content:
In this issue

The ITU-R Study Groups develop the technical bases for decisions taken at World Radiocommunication Conferences (WRCs) and develop global standards (Recommendations), Reports and Handbooks on radiocommunication matters.

This brochure presents a comprehensive overview of the work carried out by the Radiocommunication Sector of the ITU and its various entities.

title: Use of G.hn in Industrial Applications
content:
In this issue

Power-line communication (PLC) provides a cost-effective way to enable digital transformation for traditional industrial businesses. Recommendation ITU-T G.9960/1, known as “G.hn” is a unified protocol for multi-media (power line, coax, twisted pair and plastic fiber), continuously evolving to expand its capability for industrial applications.

title: ITU COP Guidelines for Industry
content:
In this issue

Businesses must increasingly put children’s interests at the heart of their work, paying special heed to protecting the privacy of young users’ personal data, preserving their right to freedom of expression, combating the growing scourge of child sexual abuse material and ensuring there are systems in place to effectively address violations of children’s rights when they occur.
Where domestic laws have not yet caught up with international law, every business will have an opportunity – and a responsibility – to bring its own operational frameworks into line with the very highest standards and best practices.

title: ITU COP Guidelines for Policy-Makers
content:
In this issue

The ITU-R Study Groups develop the technical bases for decisions taken at World Radiocommunication Conferences (WRCs) and develop global standards (Recommendations), Reports and Handbooks on radiocommunication matters. This brochure presents a comprehensive overview of the work carried out by the Radiocommunication Sector of the ITU and its various entities.

title: ITU COP Guidelines for Parents and Educators (on Child Online Protection)
content:
In this issue

On the one hand, the Internet supplies children with educational games, fun activities, and many different ways to share, to learn, and to connect meaningfully to friends, family and the outside world. On the other hand, dangers ranging from issues of privacy, fake news and deep fakes, to violent and inappropriate content, Internet scammers, and the spectre of online grooming and sexual abuse and exploitation, not to mention the unexpected impact of Covid-19, lurk in the darkness of the digital world.

The ITU COP Guidelines have been reviewed to reflect the very significant shifts in the digital landscape in which today’s children find themselves.

title: Digiworld – An example of how the ITU COP Guidelines can be delivered in practice
content:
In this issue

Explore how the ITU Guidelines on child online protection  for 8industry and policy-makers, parents, educators and children can be delivered effectively through cross-sector partnerships, co-design with local audiences and a shared vision for supporting children and families to thrive in a connected world.

title: COP Online safety activity book – Teacher’s guide
content:
In this issue

Instructions and resources for completing online safety exercises in a classroom setting with 9-12 year olds. The aim of the activities is to inspire students and teachers to have conversations about online safety issues and how to handle them.

title: U4SSC – Case study: Affordable housing and Social Inclusion
content:
In this issue

“City of Vienna: House Sharing in Urban Areas as a Tool for Social Inclusion” looks at a programme that connects students with elderly people who have a spare room or even a small apartment available in their house.   “Kirinda, Sri Lanka: Wild Coast Tented Lodge as Best Practice of Building Affordable Housing Using Local Construction Materials” examines the work of a multidisciplinary design team that created an award-winning safari camp built in close cooperation with the local community.

title: U4SSC – City solid waste management
content:
In this issue

Cities are responsible for 50 per cent of the waste generated globally and are causing between 60 and 80 per cent of greenhouse gas emissions globally. Against this background, concepts such as circular economy are particularly important, even more so when cities consume three quarters of natural resources.  In this context, recycling can transform waste into a valuable resource.  In this context, recycling can transform waste into a valuable resource. Even plastic waste can be repurposed for road construction.

title: U4SSC – Case study: Energy efficiency in buildingsa0
content:
In this issue

The rapid growth of Toronto comes with opportunities and challenges: if on the one hand it places huge pressure on the city’s already constrained electricity grid  and makes it harder to reduce total greenhouse gas  emissions, on the other hand it also provides Toronto with the scale and resources to invest in transformative strategies.

title: U4SSC – Circularity to Promote Local Businesses and Digitization
content:
In this issue

Nowadays, cities around the world are facing several challenges. Rapid urbanisation is adding pressure to create more liveable cities, to manage natural resources more efficiently whilst protecting the environment, and to meet the challenges of climate change. Increasingly, cities are recognising the importance of circular economy as a means of addressing these issues and making cities healthy and enjoyable places to live.

tag: SDG 8 Decent Work and Economic Growth
title: U4SSC – Participatory Urban Planning – Melbourne: Australia place-making case
content:
In this issue

The City of Melbourne and Village Well, an Australian place-making consultancy company, developed a cooperation project on sharing public spaces with the aim to apply the concept of place-making to engage community members locally; to enhance public spaces; and to contribute to a healthy sustainable community. Place-making is defined as the new environmentalism, using processes, tools and practices to create liveable and resilient cities, towns, communities and places.

title: U4SSC – Reducing Food Waste
content:
In this issue

Two case studies are reviewed in the light of the Zero Hunger Challenge launched in 2012 during the Rio+20 World Conference on Sustainable Development. It called, among others, for all food systems to be sustainable. The Mumbai project is expected to mitigate the challenges of hunger in a city where 41 per cent of people are forced to live in slums. The Oslo project presents a circular waste management system where the waste is used as raw materials in industry.

title: U4SSC – Re-use of Consumer Goods and Tools Loaning
content:
In this issue

The Toronto Tool Library and Sharing Depot started with the assumption that there are already enough resources available to meet the demand of communities. The Tool Library’s goal was to provide patrons with the physical tools required to take on their projects. A makerspace was later launched where members can use the tools onsite to complete projects rather than transporting them back and forth to the library. Both programmes, the library and makerspace, generate revenue for the organization and the makerspace also hosts workshops to teach woodworking, electronics and other skills

title: U4SSC – Urban Mobility – Dubai: Mobile solutions for ordering taxis and other transportation services, ‘E-hailing’ in Dubai
content:
In this issue

The project is part of a broader vision for smart cities that aims to make Dubai the happiest city on Earth. It is also aligned with the strategy of the Roads and Transport Authoriy to deliver safe and smooth transport for all,  via four key strategic goals: Smart Dubai, Integrated Dubai, People Happiness, and Smooth Transport for All.

title: U4SSC – A Guide to Circular Cities
content:
In this issue

The concept of a circular economy has recently emerged as a vision for how to gradually move away from the linear model of production and management of goods to one that, by using resources better, is not only more sustainable, but creates a range of new opportunities for inclusive economic growth.This document contains a circular city implementation framework that is designed to improve circularity in cities and support stakeholders in implementing circular actions. The framework  consists of a four-step methodology that provides a consistent method for assessing, prioritising and catalysing different circular actions.

title: Guide on the use of ITU-T L-series Recommendations related to optical technologies for outside plant
content:
In this issue

Latest figures show that while Internet use continues to spread, the digital gender gap is also growing. More effective action is urgently needed to address a range of barriers – cultural, financial and skills-related – that are impeding Internet uptake, especially among women. This report is a powerful tool to better understand connectivity issues, including the growing digital gender divide, at a time when over half of the world’s population is using the Internet.

title: Digital Skills Assessment Guidebook 2020
content:
In this issue

This guidebook can be used to determine the existing supply of a digitally skilled cohort at a national level, to assess skills demand from industry and other sectors, to identify skills gaps, and to develop policies to address future digital skills requirements. A must-have for policy-makers and other stakeholders.

title: ITU News Magazine – Technology driving safe roads
content:
In this issue

Welcome to ITU News Magazine – your source for insight on key ITU events and initiatives, as well as global information and communication technology (ICT) trends.


Read this issue for:
– How the auto and ICT sectors are merging
– What experts discussed at the Future Networked Car Symposium
– ITU’s role in future networked cars and intelligent transport.
Browse other editions of the ITU News Magazine here.

title: ICT Price Trends 2019
content:
In this issue

This report monitors the affordability of ICT services by analysing and comparing price data for mobile-voice services, mobile data and fixed broadband. It reports on the affordability gap between developed and developing countries and provides information on countries’ progress towards achieving the United Nations Broadband Commission for Sustainable Development target for 2025.

title: Performance metrics for end-to-end IPTV video quality
content:
In this issue

This Technical Paper describes useful QoS performance metrics for the video quality of IPTV services in all domains of IPTV architecture intended to enhance end-to-end video quality. It also includes detailed explanations of measurement methodologies on each domain, from head-end to home network.

title: Economic contribution of broadband, digitization and ICT regulation: Econometric Modelling for the ITU Europe region
content:
In this issue

A global econometric analysis of robust and reliable data resources to measure the impact of fixed and mobile broadband and digital transformation on the economy as a whole. This report also focuses on the impact of broadband, digital transformation and policy and regulatory frameworks on the growth of markets for digital services in the Europe region.

title: Economic contribution of broadband, digitization and ICT regulation: Econometric modelling for the ITU Commonwealth of Independent States region
content:
In this issue

Which technologies should become a policy priority in terms of adoption? How to ensure that, beyond broadband adoption, policies further develop the digital ecosystem? This report provides substantial evidence regarding the impact of broadband and digital transformation on the economy as well as the impact of institutional and regulatory variables on the growth of the digital ecosystem of the CIS region.

title: Frontier technologies to protect environment and tackle the climate change
content:
In this issue

Although still considered frontier or emerging, the eight technologies covered by this report offer real and innovative solutions to meet the needs of the world’s population, while addressing some of the needs of our planet. Introducing these technologies could bring about concrete results for city authorities and for local populations. Furthermore, ensuring the affordable and wide-scale deployment of AI and IoT in particular will spur further advancements in and wider adoption of all other frontier technologies to combat climate change.

title: Cloud computing: From paradigm to operation
content:
In this issue

Cloud services provide on-demand access to advanced ICT resources, enabling innovators to gain new capabilities without investing in new hardware or software. Cloud concepts are also fundamental to the evolution of ICT networking, helping networks to meet the requirements of an increasingly diverse range of ICT applications.
ITU standards provide the requirements and functional architectures of the cloud ecosystem. This compendium of ITU cloud standards will provide ICT industry players with a valuable point of reference as they transform networking operations to take full advantage of cloud capabilities.

title: Global ICT Regulatory Outlook 2020:Pointing the way forward to collaborative regulation
content:
In this issue

This year’s report features an exciting new tool that sits alongside the ITU Regulatory Tracker – the Benchmark of Fifth Generation Collaborative Regulation. It helps to fast-track collaborative, cross-sector regulation as the best and quickest means to leverage digital transformation for all. Rich in practicality, it offers metrics to assess gaps, proposes smart roadmaps through shifting regulatory landscapes, tracks progress, sets out new goals for regulatory excellence and proposes solutions where concrete progress towards SDGs has proved challenging.

title: Assessment of impact of wireless power transmission for electric vehicle charging on radiocommunication services
content: In this issue

title: FGVM-01R1 – Use cases and requirements for the vehicular multimedia networks
content:
In this issue

This document describes use-cases and requirements for converged network vehicular multimedia networks (VMNs), taking into account the autonomous levels defined by [SAE J3016] and used in conjunction with advanced driver assistance system (ADAS), automatic driving technologies, maps, voice commands or natural language processing.

title: ICT infrastructure business planning toolkit
content:
In this issue

As of the end of 2018, more than half of the global population is connected to and uses the Internet. To advance the UN Sustainable Development Goals, ICT infrastructure needs to be built out in unserved and underserved populations. ICT Infrastructure Business Planning Toolkit explores several key areas of development that needs to take place in order to get the whole world connected. These ICT infrastructure development tools include access to networks, regulatory policies, estimating broadband demand and revenues, estimating investments in fixed and mobile broadband, estimating operational expenses and weighted average capital costs, and reviewing the financing mechanisms of broadband infrastructure enablement. The toolkit is written for regulators and policy-makers to offer a clear and practical methodology for accurately evaluating the economic impact of broadband infrastructure and create effective infrastructure deployment plans.

title: Emergency telecommunications table-top simulation guide
content:
In this issue

Be prepared for when disasters strike! This guide will help stakeholders working on disaster management and disaster risk at national level to plan, design and conduct table-top simulations that test and refine emergency telecommunication plans and policies and verify whether networks, redundant communications capacity, personnel, and other telecommunication systems are in place.

title: SS7 vulnerabilities and mitigation measures for digital financial services transactions
content:
In this issue

This Technical Report contains the result of the Financial Inclusion Global Initiative (FIGI) security infrastructure workstream research into SS7 vulnerabilities and their effect on digital financial services (DFS) in the developing world. It describes the researched vulnerabilities and the mitigation measures for operators and DFS providers.

title: Guideline for general test procedure and specification for measurements of the LTE, 3G/2G user equipment/mobile stations (UE/MS)  for over-the-air performance testing
content:
In this issue

Typical conformance tests include transmitter maximum output power, spectrum emission mask, spurious emissions, minimum output power, and adjacent channel leakage power ratio, as well as receiver adjacent channel selectivity, blocking characteristics, spurious response, intermodulation characteristics, spurious emissions, and reference sensitivity level.

This Technical Paper gives an analysis of the work in relevant standards development organisations and a survey of the requirements, and then describes a common testing methodology for LTE, 3G/2G user equipment/mobile stations (UE/MS) for over-the air (OTA) performance testing.

title: Planning analysis for the HD Radio system in the MF band
content:
In this issue

The HD Radio hybrid configuration makes use of the existing MF Band allocations and embeds new audio and data services within an analogue 10 kHz frequency raster.

title: Digital terrestrial broadcasting systems
content:
In this issue

There is an increasing worldwide demand for suitable means of broadcasting high-quality sound, multimedia and TV programmes to vehicular, portable and fixed receivers. Digital terrestrial broadcasting offers the potential for new and improved services to consumers, with such advantages as high reliability of service for practically unlimited number of users, free-to-air access, possibility of fixed and mobile reception, etc.

This Report reviews the general characteristics of the systems for digital terrestrial sound, multimedia and TV broadcasting for fixed, portable and mobile reception.

title: Economic contribution of broadband, digitization and ICT regulation: Econometric modelling for Arab States
content:
In this issue

The transformative power of digital technologies and connectivity is empowering people, creating an environment that nurtures innovation, and is triggering positive change in business processes and in the global economy.  Discover how broadband technologies and effective ICT regulation can have positive impacts on the growth of national economies and prosperity in the Arab States region.

title: The ITU Guidelines for National Emergency Telecommunication Plans
content:
In this issue

An invaluable aid to increase preparedness of the emergency communications sector for when disasters strike. This guide outlines the key steps and phases of planning, designing, conducting and following up of an emergency simulation exercise, with templates, checklists and guidance to assist in running a simulation, and other resource materials.

title: List VIII – List of International Monitoring Stations 2019
content:
In this issue

This list contains relevant information on centralizing offices, an index of monitoring stations, and particulars of monitoring stations carrying out measurements related to terrestrial and space radiocommunication stations. An electronic map of monitoring stations and geographical zones for HF broadcasting (CIRAF zones) is also included.
This publication is available for purchase in multi-lingual CD format (Arabic, Chinese, English, French, Russian and Spanish) and direct download for CHF 80. Free download is available for members with TIES access.
To order your personal copy, please complete the form and the ITU Client Service will contact you to finalize your purchase.

title: ITU Journal (ICT Discoveries) – Propagation modelling for advanced future radio systems – Challenges for a congested radio spectrum
content:
In this issue

This special issue of the ITU Journal: ICT Discoveries considers the wide range of radio wave propagation phenomena and their effect on radiocommunication systems performance, availability and reliability. This publication explores the latest developments concerning propagation modelling and the phenomena relevant to the planning and deployment of advanced future radiocommunication systems and the efficient use of the radio spectrum.

title: Technical and operating parameters and spectrum use for short-range radiocommunication devices
content:
In this issue

This Report sets out common technical and non-technical parameters for short-range radiocommunication devices (SRDs) and widely recognized approaches for managing their use on a national basis.

title: Economic contribution of broadband, digitization and ICT regulation: Econometric modelling for Asia-Pacific
content:
In this issue

The transformative power of digital technologies and connectivity is empowering people, creating an environment that nurtures innovation, and triggering positive change in business processes and in the global economy.
By applying the same methodologies and econometric models used for assessing global effects, this study focuses on the impact of broadband, digital transformation and policy and regulatory frameworks on the growth of markets for digital services in the Asia-Pacific region. It also provides evidence of the importance of regulatory and institutional variables in driving digital growth, illustrating that broadband technologies and effective ICT regulation can have positive impacts on the development of national economies and prosperity.

title: Sharing and compatibility studies of HAPS systems in the fixed service in the 47.2-47.5 GHz and 47.9-48.2 GHz frequency ranges
content:
In this issue

This Report includes the sharing and compatibility studies of HAPS systems in the 47.2-47.5 and 47.9-48.2 GHz frequency ranges with services to which the bands are allocated on a primary basis.

It also provides the sharing and compatibility studies referenced under further resolves 1 of Resolution 160 (WRC-15), to ensure the protection of the existing services allocated to the frequency range and taking into account relevant footnotes of Article 5 of the RR.

title: Kaleidoscope 2019 – ICT for Health
content:
In this issue

The annual ITU Kaleidoscope academic conference was held in Atlanta, Georgia, in 2019. Its theme was “ICT for Health: Networks, Standards and Innovation”. ITU Kaleidoscope 2019: ICT for Health provides an overview of the event. Special sessions included research on ICT infrastructure for healthcare, medical ICT, medical Internet of Things, digital health strategies, smart technologies for care-givers, and safety and security in health-care. Each paper highlights a key issue with artificial intelligence in the sector, with the aim of working towards international standards to govern AI in healthcare.

title: Network 2030 – New Services and Capabilities for Network 2030: Description, Technical Gap and Performance Target Analysis
content:
In this issue

This document introduces new communication services and capabilities for Network 2030, including common terminology and definitions necessary for describing new services. It also analyses gaps in existing communication technology, and specifies performance targets for different type of new services and capabilities.

title: Be He@lthy Be Mobile – Personas Toolkit 2019
content:
In this issue

The Be He@lthy, Be Mobile initiative strives to educate patients in the World Heath Organization (WHO) and International Telecommunication Union (ITU) mHealth programmes to stop avoidable conditions in order to reduce health risks. Be He@lthy Be Mobile – Personas Toolkit 2019 teaches health care providers how to identify patients by using personas. It covers when to use personas, how to design effective personas using audience segmentation, how to use personas to affect better health and promote empathy, and how to design an effective mHealth programme based on your various user types. This in-depth toolkit will teach you everything you need to know about audience personas, and includes templates so you don’t start from scratch.

title: Distributed ledger technologies: Use cases
content:
In this issue

Based on a focus group survey, this technical paper showcases multiple proposed distributed ledger technology (DLT) projects. Use cases represent the vertical domains of finance, healthcare, information and communication technology (ICT), entertainment, industry, and the public sector. Horizontally, they include identity management, security, data management, governance, and crypto-infrastructure. Distributed Ledger Technologies: Use Cases delves into transparency and trust, security management, economic and social incentives, efficiency and complexity reduction, disintermediation, and identity management of DLT. It also discusses the barriers to mass DLT adoption and the significance to sustainable development goals. Barriers to adoption discussed include general risks, knowledge risks, ecosystem barriers, DLT intrinsic features, and legal considerations. After reviewing almost 40 use cases, the authors give their recommendations to standards-makers, policy-makers, industry leaders, DLT implementers, and general parties interested in distributed ledger technology.

title: Distributed ledger technologies: Regulatory framework
content:
In this issue

The rise of distributed ledger technology (DLT) has presented challenges for regulatory agencies and policy-makers. Distributed Ledger Technologies: Regulatory Framework presents a framework for regulating DLT with recommendations for users and regulators. It begins by identifying regulatory challenges and key DLT features. Addressing five categories of laws that address DLT systems, the paper continues to show how policy-makers can implement a legal framework that effectively governs the features and use cases of the technology. Categories of laws explored include legislation addressing DLT systems such as code and intellectual property; governance; DLT use cases such as crypto-currency, tokenomics, anti-money laundering and privacy, and consumer law; civil liability and consortia; and legislation that addresses the different layers of DLT structures. The aim is to give policy-makers the tools to manage civil and criminal liability, control management supervision of network participants, provide authoritative sources of data, make DLT records “legal proof,” and protect personal data and make it compatible with existing regulations.

title: Overview of remote captioning services
content:
In this issue

Remote captioning is technology that allows video presentations to be captioned in real time from a remote location. The services are utilized by the deaf, hard of hearing, and people with reading disabilities or other language difficulties. Transcribed text is streamed live during an event using an Internet-based platform so that no one misses out the presentation. Overview of Remote Captioning Services is a technical report from the ITU that outlines the benefits of remote captioning and the technical aspects of remote-captioning equipment. The security of the technology is also discussed, along with compliance with data-protection regulation compliance, encryption and the quality of remote captioning.

title: Interoperability design guidelines for personal health systems: Services interface: FHIR Observation Upload for trial implementation
content:
In this issue

The Continua Design Guidelines (CDG) define a framework for the interoperability of personal connected health data and devices. Interoperability Design Guidelines for Personal Health Systems: Services Interface: FHIR Observation Upload for Trial Implementation defines the guidelines for uploading measurements from a personal health gateway to a health and fitness service. The report analyzes several scenarios and use cases to show how patient health information can be stored safely and how patient identities can be managed effectively. One scenario deals with communicating a “Logical ID” to a patient resource. Another scenario illustrates how a patient designator can be used to establish patient identity. A third shows the patient designator as generated by the FHIR (Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resource) on the health and fitness service. The report recommends normative guidelines for measuring uploads and reporting patient information.

title: Conventional digital land mobile radio systems
content:
In this issue

This Report deals with the technical and operational characteristics of conventional (non-cellular) digital land mobile radio (CDLMR) systems that provide capabilities required for specific user groups/applications such as governmental, mining, health, hospitality, transportations, disaster relief, industrial, manufacturing, construction, etc. It also includes information on approaches to frequency assignments for CDLMR.

title: Digital transformation and the role of enterprise architecture
content:
In this issue

Investing in critical digital enterprise architecture is becoming more important for governments and public organizations, but there are only a handful of successful cases to look to for examples on how to make the transition. Digital Transformation and the Role of Enterprise Architecture identifies eight first-level building blocks that are required to transform public organizations to provide digital services. It challenges organizations to think strategically about deploying those building blocks to develop a digital platform for delivering critical services. Using samples from digital leaders who have made the transformation, this guide helps other public agencies ready to build out their digital architecture and to do it effectively, efficiently, and successfully.

title: Usage scenarios, requirements and technical elements of a global platform for the broadcasting service
content:
In this issue

Personal computers, smartphones and tablets are increasingly used to access media services.  Audiences increasingly expect, from a technical perspective, to be able to watch linear and non-linear broadcast content anytime, anywhere and on any audio-visual device, both stationary and in motion. This trend is fully recognized and supported – to the extent possible – by today’s broadcasters, who naturally seek to deliver their range of content and services to all interested users on a device of their choice and in their preferred environment.

This report covers the requirements of a global platform, which is a delivery platform to facilitate distribution of broadcast content to end-users with various receiving devices in multiple reception environments, implemented by using both broadcasting and non-broadcasting technologies.

title: Integrated broadcast-broadband systems
content:
In this issue

In a media scenario where convergent TV receivers are able to handle not only the broadcast signal but also applications delivered by broadband IP telecommunication services, there are opportunities to drive user engagement and to maximize the end-user’s satisfaction by offering a range of new
services. A system which enables to offer such services is called Integrated broadcast-broadband (IBB) system.

Part 1 of this report provides an overview of IBB systems and Part 2 offers general considerations to build IBB services.

title: Methods for the evaluation of the quality of service of second generation DTTB systems
content:
In this issue

This Report introduces methods that have been used for evaluating the quality of service of second-generation digital television broadcasting systems using the VHF and UHF bands.

title: National approaches of some countries on the implementation of terrestrial IMT systems in bands identified for IMT
content:
In this issue

This Report presents national approaches taken and/or knowledge gained by certain countries in the use/deployment or planning of terrestrial component of International Mobile Telecommunications (IMT) in certain frequency bands that are allocated to the mobile service and identified for IMT, which includes regulatory, technical and operational aspects.

title: 2019 – Report on Turning Digital Technology Innovation into Climate Action
content:
In this issue

Information and communication technologies (ICTs) offer solutions to monitor, mitigate and adapt to the impacts of climate change. The evidence and case studies presented in this report cover the full range of measures that are being deployed to better understand the Earth’s system, reduce greenhouse gas emissions and build resilience to the climate crisis – from using space sensing observation to track deforestation to developing smart grids to accelerate the energy transition to strengthening early-warnings systems against the rising number of extreme weather events.

title: Characteristics of digital terrestrial broadcasting systems in the frequency band 174-230 MHz
content:
In this issue

This Report contains a summary of the reference technical and operational characteristics of Band III (174-230 MHz) digital terrestrial broadcasting (DTB) systems, television and sound, required for relevant sharing studies in Regions 1, 2 and 3.

title: Guidance for selection of system parameters and implementation of second generation DTTB systems
content:
In this issue

This Report provides guidance where an existing DTTB network exists and how assessment of parameters for the second generation can be reliably chosen to either: maintain the same coverage; improve the coverage; maintain the same data bit rate in a 6/7/8 MHz channel; improve the data bit rate in a 6/7/8 MHz channel; obtain a mode with more robustness to interference; evaluate a mode with less robustness to interference while enhanced with other features; and consider the consequences to the receiving audience of the characteristics to be selected.

title: Planning parameters for terrestrial digital sound broadcasting systems in VHF bands
content:
In this issue

This Report provides planning parameters for the following digital terrestrial broadcasting systems: system C (also known as HD Radio), system G (also known as DRM+), system A (also known as DAB) and RAVIS system in VHF Bands. It also defines a framework for calculating all relevant network planning parameters that are very similar for the systems.

title: Multichannel sound technology in home and broadcasting applications
content:
In this issue

Multichannel stereo as well as 2-channel stereo audio services are widely used as part of digital broadcasting services. This Report contains information on the subject of multichannel sound technologies in home and broadcasting applications beyond the 5.1 sound system specified in Recommendation ITU-R BS.775.

title: Small Island Developing States (SIDS) and ICT: Mid-term review of the Samoa Pathway
content:
In this issue

Mobile broadband coverage in the SIDS has risen from 50 per cent of the population to 85 per cent and the price of 500 megabits of mobile data has virtually halved, falling from 15 per cent of gross national income (GNI) per capita to 8 per cent. Overall, SIDS are largely on track to achieve universality and affordability targets for Internet access by 2020. This document reviews progress made in addressing the priorities of SIDS through implementation of the SIDS Accelerated Modalities of Action (SAMOA) Pathway.

title: Sharing between 50/40 GHz geostationary networks and non-geostationary systems
content:
In this issue

The work represented in this document seeks to develop a regulatory framework to facilitate co-frequency operation of GSO networks and non-GSO FSS systems in the 50/40 GHz frequency bands.

title: U4SSC – Case study – Fine dust filtration in Stuttgart, Germany
content:
In this issue

Eighteen cities in Germany are not in compliance with air-borne pollutant standards. In most cases, this is due to high levels of nitrogen dioxide (NO2). Both the European Union Commission and the non-governmental organization Deutsche Umwelthilfe (DUH) have taken legal action against Germany for its violations, indicating a critical need to address this issue. One of the cities affected is Stuttgart. Case Study – Fine Dust Filtration in Stuttgart, Germany shows how the implementation of a smart filtration system at the Neckartor road junction in Stuttgart in 2018 has impacted fine dust pollution along the Neckartor corridor. The paper describes the pilot project, its implementation and management, and concludes with a future plan for scaling up and continuing to study how technology can be used to reduce air pollution in Stuttgart.

title: U4SSC – City Science Application Framework
content:
In this issue

Based on the initiatives of the United 4 Smart Sustainable Cities (U4SSC), City Science Application Framework details a four-step methodology for cities to solve their most pressing challenges. Using empirical evidence, the framework shows how to assess, prioritize and boost city applications. Beginning with an introduction to urbanization, the report provides an overview of the city science application framework while listing the ways in which it can be used to solve the problems of urbanization. The report goes on to list the stakeholders involved in city applications and shows how they can work together while implementing the framework. It also lists city science enablers — policy tools that allow a city to boost its science application framework. These include international standards and guidance, R&D programmes, laws and regulations, and financial incentives. The report contains a series of case studies to further enlighten city science.

title: U4SSC – Case study – Unlocking the potential of trust-based AI for city science and smarter cities
content:
In this issue

In recent years, people have been moving from the countryside to cities in huge numbers. The urban population around the world is expected to reach 5 billion by 2030, bringing huge opportunities for the economic and social development of cities but also placing a strain on infrastructure and amplifying the challenges posed by energy use and climate change and threats to health and the environment. Unlocking the Potential of Trust-Based AI for City Science and Smarter Cities is a case study, part of the United 4 Smart Sustainable Cities initiative, that highlights the need to manage governance and service delivery to mitigate some of the effects of rapid urbanization. The emerging model of connected, smart cities leverages new technologies such as artificial intelligence, the Internet of Things, big data and real-time control, with the data being fed into intelligent applications for transport, healthcare and the environment to optimize city living. The report explores the opportunities of managed growth in smart cities, but also the security and privacy threats.

title: U4SSC – Case study – Smart Dubai – Happiness Meter in Dubai, United Arab Emirates
content:
In this issue

In 2014, Sheikh Mohammad Bin Rashid Al Maktoum, vice-president and prime minister of the United Arab Emirates, established Dubai’s smart initiative around the vision of becoming the happiest city on Earth. The goal is to implement innovative technology that will make city experiences safe, seamless, personalized and efficient while enhancing the quality of life for its citizens. In order to measure the happiness of its citizens through feedback from them, the Smart Dubai initiative utilizes a tool called Happiness Meter. Case Study – Smart Dubai Happiness Meter in Dubai, United Arab Emirates showcases the implementation of the Smart Dubai initiative and the Happiness Meter to show how digital transformation has impacted the social, economic and environmental well-being of the people living in Dubai.

title: U4SSC – Case study – Air quality management in Southern California, USA
content:
In this issue

The San Francisco Bay area has grown from a population of 5 million in 1980 to an estimated 7.756 million in 2017. The South Coast Air Quality Management District (SCAQMD) is made up of four counties (Los Angeles, Orange, Riverside, and San Bernardino) with an estimated population of 17 million. Case Study – Air Quality Management in Southern California, USA visualizes air quality data in these two areas so that regulators can see issues clearly and quickly, identify who is responsible for air quality, and assess the impact California’s air quality initiatives have on the community in real time. The case study shows how smart technology is being used in Southern California and how the data presented can be used to improve air quality management in these districts and expanded to other districts.

title: U4SSC – Case study – Data driven energy savings in the Hyperdome shopping centre in Queensland, Australia
content:
In this issue

Logan City in Queensland has about 320,000 residents, 50 per cent of whom are under 30 — and being a young city has forged a desire to limit the impact of climate change. In an effort to achieve this, city leaders encouraged changes that would optimize the building operations of the city’s largest shopping centre. Hyperdome attracts thousands of visitors and uses a significant amount of energy, but by installing a digital platform connected to the centre’s building management system, project leaders can monitor and manage energy use.  Data Driven Energy Savings in the Hyperdome Shopping Centre in Queensland, Australia, part of the United 4 Smart Sustainable Cities initiative, highlights how data from Internet-of-Things sensors feeds into the system to illustrate patterns of energy consumption, allowing managers to fine-tune the operation of cooling and air-ventilation units and reduce peak demand. This case study sets out how the project was implemented, the energy and costs saved, and the possibilities for buildings in other cities.

title: U4SSC – Case study – Crime prediction for more agile policing in cities – Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
content:
In this issue

Rio de Janeiro is the second most populated municipality in Brazil and the sixth most populated in the Americas. Designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site and home to many prominent educational institutions, thriving industries, and beautiful landscapes, the economic disparity between the rich and poor is drastic. In 2017, Brazil experienced a murder rate of 30.8 per 100,000 people. Crime Prediction for More Agile Policing in Cities – Rio de Janeiro, Brazil is a case study that shows how leaders in Rio predicted the crime rate and developed an agile policy to lower it. The city developed a digital platform that can predict crime based on available crime data and used its predictive analytics model to police crime while facing challenges of using artificial intelligence as a tool for crime prevention. Based on this study, authorities believe predictive analytics can be used to predict crime in other localities.

title: U4SSC – Case study – Smart Dubai – Rashid – City Concierge
content:
In this issue

Dubai, one of the seven emirates of the United Arab Emirates, is one of the largest cities in the world and a major economic center in the Arabic Gulf region. On a 40-year digital transformation journey to make Dubai one of the most visited global cities and the happiest city on Earth, the Smart Dubai initiative is the region’s answer to the Fourth Industrial Revolution. Focused on three emerging technologies (artificial intelligence, blockchain, and Internet of Things), Case Study – Smart Dubai – Rashid – City Concierge details these initiatives with a special emphasis on the city’s digital concierge, code-named Rashid. The case study details the vision and content of the concierge, its implementation, and the results. This case study illustrates why and how Dubai is on target to achieve its goal of being the happiest city on Earth.

title: U4SSC – Case study – Identifying the cascading effects on vital objects during flooding
content:
In this issue

When a flood engulfs a city, the first problem is the water itself, the second problem is the effect of the flooding on vital infrastructure. Part of the United 4 Smart Sustainable Cities initiative, Identifying Cascading Effects on Vital Objects During Flooding is a case study on the development in Holland of a computational model that simulates the impact of a breached dike. Trialled in Rotterdam, it shows how the water cascades through the city and how hospitals and energy and transport networks are affected. The innovation is one of the strands of Adaptive Circular Cities, a Dutch project that aims to encourage people to live more sustainably, and the benefits of such advance information could be huge: greater readiness for a disaster, more resilient cities, better rescue efforts and the saving of lives.

title: Guidance for operational practices in HDR television production
content:
In this issue

These operational practices are intended to provide initial guidance to help ensure optimum and consistent use of high dynamic range in television production using the Perceptual Quantization (PQ) and Hybrid Log-Gamma (HLG) methods specified in Recommendation ITU-R BT.2100. They should be read in conjunction with Report ITU-R BT.2390, which provides additional background information.

title: High dynamic range television for production and international programme exchange
content:
In this issue

Recommendation ITU-R BT.2100 (Image parameter values for high dynamic range television for use in production and international programme exchange) specifies parameters for High Dynamic Range television (HDR-TV) signals to be used for programme production and international programme exchange.

This Report provides background information on HDR in general, and for the perceptual quantization (PQ) and hybrid log-gamma (HLG) HDR signal parameters specified in the Recommendation.

title: HDTV and UHDTV including HDR-TV test materials for assessment of picture quality
content:
In this issue

This Report contains lists of HDTV, UHDTV including HDR-TV test materials and related information for assessment of picture quality of television systems.

title: Guidelines for the use of the ITU-R ADM Renderer
content:
In this issue

This Report provides guidelines for the use of the ITU-R ADM Renderer, which can be seen as part of the evolution, or an extension, of mixers and down-mixers that are often used today, where the principal of allowing creative control of the listening experience is continued or extended into the environment of Advanced Sound Systems.

Advanced Sound Systems (AdvSS) technology is a new challenge for the broadcast and broadband industries. The ADM Renderer is also a bridge between today’s audio production and the new world of AdvSS.

title: The State of Broadband 2019: Broadband as a Foundation for Sustainable Development
content:
In this issue

2019 marks the first full year when more than half of the world has begun to participate online in the global digital economy. This year also marks the 30th birthday of the World Wide Web, and 25 years since the first e-commerce transaction.
Fifty years on, the internet’s growth is maturing. Hundreds of millions of new users still are coming online every year, but overall growth is slowing, both as a function of the large existing user base, and because of significant challenges in reaching those not yet connected.

title: Economic impact of broadband in LDCs, LLDCs and SIDS – An empirical study
content:
In this issue

Ninety-one countries fall into three developing nations categories: Least developed countries (LDCs), landlocked developing countries (LLDCs), and small island developing states (SIDS). These 91 nations have largely been left out of studies on the economic impact of fixed and mobile broadband. Economic Impact of Broadband in LDCs, LLDCs, and SIDS (An Empirical Study) fixes that. This empirical study delves deep into how broadband investment can lead to higher economic returns in these countries. Authors use cross-sectional time-series analysis to study the subject in these 91 nation-states from 2000 to 2017 and confirm that there is a positive economic impact from investing in fixed and mobile broadband in these countries. It measures the direct and indirect impact in several economic sectors including agriculture, education, financial services, government, health, and disaster management,  of that investment.

title: Sharing and compatibility studies of HAPS systems in the fixed service in the 27.9-28.2 GHz and 31.0-31.3 GHz frequency ranges
content:
In this issue

This Report includes the sharing and compatibility studies of HAPS systems in the 27.9-28.2 GHz and 31.0-31.3 GHz frequency ranges with services to which the bands are allocated on a primary basis, to ensure the protection of the existing services allocated to these frequency ranges and taking into account relevant footnotes of Article 5 of the RR.

title: Sharing and compatibility studies of High Altitude Platform Station systems in the fixed service in the 38-39.5 GHz frequency range
content:
In this issue

This Report includes the sharing and compatibility studies of High Altitude Platform Station (HAPS) systems in the 38-39.5 GHz frequency range with the Fixed Service (FS), the Mobile Service (MS) and the Fixed Satellite Service (FSS) to which the bands are allocated on a primary basis, and also with the Space Research Service (SRS) in the adjacent band.

It also provides the sharing and compatibility studies referenced under further resolves 1 of Resolution 160 (WRC-15), to ensure the protection of the existing services allocated to the frequency range and taking into account relevant footnotes of Article 5 of the RR.

title: Operation of earth stations in motion communicating with geostationary space stations in the fixed-satellite service allocations at 17.7-19.7 GHz and 27.5-29.5 GHz
content:
In this issue

This Report describes ESIM operation (M-ESIM, A-ESIM, and L-ESIM) in the frequency bands 17.7-19.7 GHz and 27.5-29.5 GHz, and capture the results of studies called with existing services in those bands. Issues covered include ESIM user needs, characteristics and spectrum use of ESIM, consideration of ESIM compatibility with other services and applications, and regulatory issues.

title: Sharing and compatibility studies of HAPS systems in the fixed service in the 24.25 27.5 GHz frequency range in Region 2
content:
In this issue

This Report includes the sharing and compatibility studies of HAPS systems in the 21.4-22 GHz frequency range with services to which the bands are allocated on a primary basis. It also provides the sharing and compatibility studies referenced under further resolves 1 of Resolution 160 (WRC-15), to ensure the protection of the existing services allocated to the frequency range, and taking into account relevant footnotes of Article 5 of the RR.

title: Sharing and compatibility studies of HAPS systems in the fixed service in the 21.4 22 GHz frequency range for Region 2
content:
In this issue

This Report includes the sharing and compatibility studies of HAPS systems in the 21.4-22 GHz frequency range with services to which the bands are allocated on a primary basis. It also provides the sharing and compatibility studies referenced under further resolves 1 of Resolution 160 (WRC-15), to ensure the protection of the existing services allocated to the frequency range, and taking into account relevant footnotes of Article 5 of the RR.

title: Radionavigation-satellite service applications in the 1 164-1 215 MHz, 1 215-1 300 MHz and 1 559-1 610 MHz frequency bands
content:
In this issue

This Report provides information on some current and planned RNSS applications for the 1-GHz RNSS bands (1 164-1 215 MHz, 1 215-1 300 MHz and 1 559-1 610 MHz). It includes RNSS applications not addressed in the current set of ITU-R M-Series Recommendations addressing 1-GHz RNSS issues, as well as additional information on RNSS applications that have been previously addressed.

title: DSTR-DFSMR-Main recommendations
content:
In this issue

This Technical Report outlines the main recommendations of the ITU Focus Group on Digital Financial Service (FG-DFS) and identifies key areas where intervention by regulators, DFS operators and policy-makers are needed to create a conducive environment for digital financial services.

title: Review of DFS user agreements in Africa: A consumer protection perspective
content:
In this issue

Digital financial services (DFS) has made money transfer, credit, insurance, and other products and services accessible to more people worldwide and made financial inclusion possible in developing countries. However, DFS contract clauses are often unclear or difficult to understand, onerous, lengthy, missing crucial terms, or contravene regulation or legislation. Review of DFS User Agreements in Africa: A Consumer Protection Perspective analyzes DFS contracts from 18 African countries to explore the fairness of these contracts in four key ways: the language used, obligations of DFS providers, consumer obligations, and dispute resolution measures. The report summarizes findings on these themes from nine of the countries studied with country-specific analyses that reveal the good practices and some areas of concern.

title: Technical Report D4.3 – Overview of technical enablers for trusted data
content:
In this issue

This Technical Report provides an overview of technical enablers for trusted data. It covers, among other themes, the characteristics and supporting enablers of trusted data (including the process of enabling trusted data from a record-keeping as well as from a data quality management perspective); special concerns about technical enablers to ensure trusted data; and an integrated requirements framework for technical enablers to promote trusted data.

title: Technical Report D4.1 – Framework for security, privacy, risk and governance in data processing and management
content:
In this issue

This Technical Report addresses concerns regarding data security, privacy and risk for data processing and management in IoT and Smart Cities and Communities, which all require an appropriate governance framework. It also analyses the key components of the governance framework and their impact on related lifecycles and processes, in particular on risk management processes.

title: Technical Report D3.5 – Overview of blockchain for supporting IoT and SC&C in DPM aspects
content:
In this issue

Blockchain presents opportunities for disruptive innovations, which enables global businesses to transact with less friction and more trust and efficiency.

Blockchain shows great promise across a wide range of business applications in many fields, including IoT and SC&C. There are many benefits and challenges to addressing blockchain and IoT and SC&C together. This Technical Report provides overview of blockchain aspects related to data processing and management (DPM) for IoT and SC&C.

title: Technical Report D2.3 – Web based data model for IoT and smart city
Technical Report D0.2 – Data processing and management for IoT and smart cities and communities: methodology for data processing and management
content:
In this issue

This document provides methodologies for concept and taxonomy building, which have been used in the development of the Technical Specification “Data Processing and Management for IoT and Smart Cities and Communities: Vocabulary” [FG-DPM TS D0.1] and can be used for its future continual improvement. It aims to encourage a mutual and consistent understanding of, and a coherent approach to, the activities relating to DPM, and the use of uniform terminology.

title: Commonly identified consumer protection themes for digital financial services
content:
In this issue

As digital financial services (DFS) grow and become more available to more people around the globe, the more critical a part consumer protection plays in DFS. Commonly Identified Consumer Protection Themes for Digital Financial Services explores how consumers can be protected from fraud while personal data and funds are safeguarded and transparency insured. This technical report explores four specific themes regarding consumer protection in DFS: Transparency and the provision of information, fraud prevention, dispute resolution, and data privacy and protection. Through a careful review of publications and research conducted by leading international organizations, authors explore how a consumer protection framework for DFS can be developed while keeping the sector fair and balanced for all stakeholders.

title: Methods for conversion of high dynamic range content to standard dynamic range content and vice-versa
content:
In this issue

High dynamic range (HDR) content may be converted to a significantly lower dynamic range so that it may be displayed on a standard dynamic range (SDR) display device. As the dynamic range mismatch between content and display capabilities can be significant, the manner in which the dynamic range is reduced impacts the visual quality that can be achieved. Likewise, SDR content, such as for instance legacy content, may be converted to HDR content to enable display on a HDR display device, or to bring such content into a HDR video workflow.

This Report provides guidance toward the design of methods that achieve such conversions, which are referred to as tone mapping and inverse tone mapping, and it presents example methods along with their evaluation.

title: Assessment on limitations mentioned in Annex 7 to RR Appendix 30 (Rev.WRC 15) in the 11.7-12.7 GHz band for the GSO broadcasting-satellite service in all Regions
content:
In this issue

This Report contains results of studies of the limitations mentioned in Annex 7 to RR Appendix 30 (Rev.WRC-15) as instructed by Resolution 557 (WRC-15).

title: Broadcasting-satellite service system parameters between 17.3 GHz and 42.5 GHz and associated feeder links
content:
In this issue

A technical report assembling system parameters and system characteristics for the BSS bands between 17.3 GHz and 42.5 GHz and associated feeder links.

The report includes, among others, study results for 21 GHz band broadcasting satellites, measured downlink receiving earth station antenna patterns,  examples of BSS systems utilizing the locally-variable e.i.r.p. systems in the 21 GHz band, and  a methodology to evaluate unwanted emission from 21 GHz band BSS.

tag: SDG 8 Decent Work and Economic Growth
title: Digital Skills Insights 2019
content:
In this issue

In this year’s Digital Skills Insights 2019 report, we examine the rapidly changing field of learning and skills development in the digital era. It features a range of articles from experts on how emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence and the Internet of Things, as well as advances in areas such as big data, smart cities and open-source learning, are changing how we create capacity and develop skills – now and in the future. This year’s report includes an overview of the discussion about digital literacy and new methods of teaching and creating capacity, as well as several case studies on how these new technologies are advancing skills in developing countries. The report aims to assist ITU members, as well as policy-makers and academics, in answering the question of how best to address future demand for digitally skilled citizens.

title: Technical Specification D2.1 – Data processing and management framework for IoT and smart cities and communities
content:
In this issue

This Technical Specification describes the Data Processing and Management Framework organised into five dimensions, namely data lifecycle, trust, data
commercialisation, data ecosystem and data governance.

This framework covers all IoT and Smart Cities and communities applications and services.

title: Technical Specification D1.1 – Use case analysis and requirements for Data Processing and Management to support IoT and Smart Cities and Communities
content:
In this issue

This Technical Specification introduces a unified use case template for data processing and management (DPM) to support Internet of Things and Smart Cities and Communities (IoT and SC&C), and then provides common requirements for DPM as well as use case specific requirements for DPM based on the analysis of the collected use cases.

title: Technical Specification D0.1 – Data Processing and Management for IoT and Smart Cities and Communities: Vocabulary
content:
In this issue

The terms and definitions related to Data Processing and Management (DPM) are important for deploying Internet of things (IoT) and Smart Cities and Communities (SC&C).

This Technical Specification provides a set of core terms and associated definitions to reflect basic  concepts used for DPM to support IoT and SC&C.

title: Technical Specification D5 – Data economy: commercialization, ecosystem and impact assessment
content:
In this issue

This Technical Specification specifies data commercialization, data ecosystem enhancement and data economy impact assessment as a number of key pillars comprising data economy.

title: Technical Specification D4.4 – Framework to support data quality management in IoT
content:
In this issue

This Technical Specification specifies a framework to support data quality management in IoT for the provision of quality data and services.

title: Technical Specification D3.8 – Identity framework in blockchain to support DPM for IoT and SC&C
content:
In this issue

This Technical Specification presents an identity framework in blockchains to support data processing and management (DPM) for IoT and SC&C. It covers several key requirements with respect to an identity framework in blockchain to support DPM for IoT systems and functional features to fulfil these requirements.

title: Technical Specification D3.6 – Blockchain-based data exchange and sharing for supporting IoT and SC&C
content:
In this issue

This Technical Specification provides technical descriptions and specifications of blockchain-based data exchange and sharing in Internet of things (IoT) and smart city and communities (SC&C) application domains.

The scope of this technical specification includes: overview of blockchain in data exchange and sharing;  requirements for blockchain-based data exchange and sharing;  functional models of blockchain-based data exchange and sharing;  platform of blockchain-based data exchange and sharing; and deployment modes for blockchain-based data exchange and sharing.

title: HSTP.CONF-H764 – Conformance testing specification for H.764
content:
In this issue

This Technical Paper defines the conformance testing items for Recommendation ITU-T H.764 “IPTV Service Enhanced Script Language”. It also provides testing properties and the sample codes to be tested for web-based IPTV multimedia interaction.

title: Access to payment infrastructures
content:
In this issue
