Technology has increased the role of non-bank entities in payment services. Banks have historically served in the role of retail payment service providers because their function as institutions of deposits has made it convenient and practical for them to serve that role. However, financial inclusion coupled with rapid advancement in technology in many countries has given rise to non-bank payment providers. Unfortunately, they often are not effective in using payment infrastructures to make interoperability feasible.

Digital Financial Services – Access to Payment Infrastructures provides an in-depth overview of the payments landscape globally with recommendations and case studies for all stakeholders in order to make payment infrastructures more accessible to all providers.

title: The regulator’s perspective on the right timing for inducing interoperability
content:
In this issue

Interoperability is a crucial characteristic of financial and ICT infrastructures for the purpose of fostering financial inclusion through digital financial services. While a consensus has been reached concerning the role that regulators play in making systems interoperable, the scope and timing for regulator action is still being discussed. The Regulator’s Perspective on the Right Timing for Inducing Interoperability provides an overview of DFS systems and the challenges to interoperability. Not all service providers consider it important. Nevertheless, authorities from 18 countries were surveyed to obtain their opinions on the question of the right timing for inducing interoperability in DFS. This report highlights the survey answers of authorities from five countries – Brazil, Liberia, Nigeria, Philippines and Uganda – to allow for evaluation so that regulators can learn from the lessons.

title: Competition aspects of digital financial services
content:
In this issue

As the global digital financial services (DFS) ecosystem continues to grow, it becomes increasingly more competitive. Service providers may face market access and licensing issues, challenges to telecommunications and payment infrastructure access, interoperability obstacles, funding difficulties, taxes, access to big data, and more. Digital Financial Services – Competition Aspects of Digital Financial Services delves into these issues showcasing how different countries have approached the challenges and solved them using regulation, technology and market solutions. Written with all stakeholders in mind, the report identifies market imbalances that affect policy frameworks and regulatory intervention efforts that have had an impact on the competitiveness of DFS in Bangladesh, China, Colombia, Georgia, Ghana, India, Jordan, Kenya, Malawi, Mexico, Nepal, Nigeria, Pakistan, Peru, Philippines, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Tanzania, Uganda, Zambia and Zimbabwe. Using a functional analytical approach, the study challenges policy-makers and market leaders to approach competition in DFS with care and thoughtfulness.

title: Impact of social networks on digital liquidity
content:
In this issue

Social networks provide users with valuable services, often for free. The larger networks add commercial services that earn them revenue and appeal to consumers in powerful ways, however, they often miss the bottom of the pyramid. Even though Internet adoption is growing, there is still the problem of financial inclusion. Social networks must provide financial onramps and allow users to link payment accounts. Otherwise, the problem of financial inclusion will not solved. Digital Financial Services – Impact of Social Networks on Digital Liquidity provides an in-depth overview of digital financial services and how they relate to social networks while offering stakeholders valuable and practical insight into whether or not social networks are capable of providing digital liquidity in order to provide a more fair and competitive e-commerce environment for everyone.

title: Regulation in the digital financial services ecosystem
content:
In this issue

Digital financial services has emerged as a sector worldwide that offers a viable solution to one of the financial industry’s greatest challenges -financial inclusion. Digital Financial Services – Regulation in the Digital Financial Services Ecosystem discusses the various regulatory categories related to financial inclusion including regulatory agents, consumer protection, market access, payment systems, risk management, and more. It also addresses key issues in managing the regulatory environment including how regulatory authorities can work better together and cross-border collaborations. Key considerations include Anti-Money Laundering (AML) and Know Your Customer (KYC) rules, how to combat financial terrorism, mobile network operators (MNOs), and memorandums of understanding (MOU). Authorities looking for an MOU template will find one here. The report is based on surveys of financial services regulators in various countries.

title: The digital financial services ecosystem
content:
In this issue

The digital financial services (DFS) ecosystem consists of consumers, businesses, government agencies and non-profit organizations that have a need for digital and interoperable financial products and services; the financial services providers that serve them; the infrastructure through which services are delivered; and government policies, legal frameworks and regulations. Digital financial services – The Digital Financial Services Ecosystem provides an overview of the digital financial services sector and the regulatory frameworks that govern the ecosystem. The report charts the evolution of DFS, highlights the issues and challenges within the ecosystem, and discusses the technical requirements of the products and services, while highlighting use cases.

title: Key elements for integration of satellite systems into Next Generation Access Technologies
content:
In this issue

Next-Generation Access Technologies (NGAT) are envisioned to be highly-advanced, ubiquitous, seamlessly integrated heterogeneous “network of networks” or “system of systems” conceived from the ground up and providing a wide range of services and applications.

In this context, issues such as the geographic coverage, network resilience, flexibility and efficiency will benefit from a variety of networking technologies including other non-terrestrial platforms, such as satellites. This Report provides key elements of satellite networks and use cases envisaged for NGAT.

title: Sharing with incumbent services in the 51.4-52.4 GHz band and adjacent and nearby bands
content:
In this issue

This Report provides elements related to WRC-19 agenda item 9.1, issue 9.1.9, “Studies relating to spectrum needs and possible allocation of the frequency band 51.4-52.4 GHz to the fixed-satellite service (Earth-to-space)”.

It presents the results from five compatibility studies conducted between FSS and EESS, based on specific deployment model for FSS Earth stations. Specific regulatory provisions would be required to make this deployment model relevant.

title: Introduction of additional mobile-satellite service systems into the Global Maritime Distress Safety systems
content:
In this issue

This Report addresses the introduction of additional satellite systems into the GMDSS as provided in resolves 2 of Resolution 359 (Rev.WRC-15).

title: Coexistence between the radio astronomy service and radiolocation service applications in the frequency band 76-81 GHz
content:
In this issue

This Report contains the results of sharing and compatibility studies between applications of the radio astronomy service and radiolocation service applications in the frequency band 76-81 GHz, portions of which are allocated to the radio astronomy service (RAS) either on a primary or a secondary basis.

These studies include information on measurements and national regulatory measures that may be useful in ensuring the sharing and compatibility between the radio astronomy service and vehicular radars in the 76-81 GHz band.

title: Visible light for broadband communications
content:
In this issue

This Report aims to shed light on how, in which way, and to what extent the use of (near) visible light communication (VLC) (or Optical Wireless Communication) can help ease the congestion in the radio spectrum. The development of new technologies, coupled with the use of visible light communication, could be an interesting combination and possibly conducive to a more efficient use of the radio spectrum.

title: Spectrum monitoring evolution
content:
In this issue

The goal of spectrum management is to maximize spectrum efficiency, minimize interference and eliminate unauthorized and improper use of the spectrum. As the eyes and ears of the spectrum management process, spectrum monitoring is very necessary and important in the management of spectrum resources, radio stations of various types, and the electromagnetic environment by providing valuable monitoring data, including spectrum occupancy and characteristics of signals, such as field strength, bandwidth, modulation type, locations of emitters, etc.

Radiocommunication systems are in a constant and rapid evolution. Future spectrum monitoring systems should therefore thave the capability for monitoring new radiocommunication technologies and systems, such as detection of weak signals, co-frequency signal separation and multi-mode location based on digital signal processing (DSP), RF sensor networking, and other technologies.

title: Spectrum management and monitoring during major events
content:
In this issue

Major events like the Olympics, Formula 1 races, music festivals and state visits, require a variety of radio applications (from broadcasting, police, ambulance, wireless microphones and cameras to RLANs) and radio equipment aggregated within a limited area. Adequate spectrum planning, licensing, spectrum monitoring, inspection of radio stations and processing of radio interferences are therefore essential for the successful performance of a major event. Moreover, technical equipment limitations and last-minute license applications require rapid and flexible on-site frequency management during the event itself.

The purpose of this Report is to provide guidance to administrations that are responsible for frequency management and enforcement activities such as spectrum management, spectrum monitoring and inspection of radio stations.

title: Studies on the suitability of existing allocations to the space operation service below 1 GHz and additional sharing studies on possible new and/or upgraded allocations
content:
In this issue

This Report studies the suitability of existing space operation service allocations below 1 GHz for telemetry, tracking and command in the space operation service for non-geostationary satellites with short duration missions. It also presents summaries on whether spectrum requirements can be met in the existing allocations, and if not, additional compatibility studies are presented on possible new and/or upgraded allocations.

title: Economic contribution of broadband, digitization and ICT regulation: Econometric modelling for the Americas
content:
In this issue

What has been the economic impact of broadband and digital transformation in the Americas? The Economic Contribution of Broadband, Digitization and ICT Regulation: Econometric Modelling for the Americas looks at three areas: fixed and mobile broadband, digitization, and policy and regulatory frameworks. For each country studied, the report explores the level of ICT development and asks two key questions: Which technologies should become a policy priority? How should regulators ensure that policies are deployed to stimulate the development of the digital? The report concludes that a 10 per cent increase in fixed broadband penetration would lead to a 1.9 per cent increase in GDP per capita, while a 10 per cent drop in broadband prices would result in a more than 3.0 per cent boost to broadband adoption.

title: Cooperation in the field of space radio monitoring
content:
In this issue

Due to the highly specialised and costly nature of satellite monitoring facilities, it is suitable to establish a common approach to conduct space radio monitoring. One way to do so is through establishing a Memorandum of Understanding that provides the possibility for the signing Administrations to access and undertake satellite monitoring activities.

The purpose of this Report is to describe an example of a fruitful cooperation that is the first 12 years of activities of the Memorandum of Understanding on Satellite Monitoring (SAT MoU) within some European Administrations.

title: Implementation considerations for the introduction and transition to digital terrestrial sound and multimedia broadcasting
content:
In this issue

With the transition to digital television broadcasting now well advanced, it is appropriate to consider once again why there has been inconsistent interest among administrations or demand from listeners to make a complete transition to digital sound broadcasting.

This Report highlights the benefits of digital sound broadcasting and discusses some successful implementations. It also seeks to address some of the negative comments made during public consultations, particular by consumer groups, expressed on ceasing analogue sound broadcasting, and addresses the technical and economic factors involved in bringing the advantages of digital sound broadcasting to all listeners around the world.

title: The economic contribution of broadband, digitalization and ICT regulation
content:
In this issue

There is a case for wider adoption of digital technologies and digital policies across the globe — and the maths proves it. The Economic Contribution of Broadband, Digitalization, and ICT Regulation is an ITU report that draws on statistical, economic and mathematical modelling of reliable data going back for years to show the economic impacts of fixed and mobile broadband, digitization and regulatory frameworks. It finds that fixed broadband had a significant impact on the world economy between 2010 and 2017, and that the effect was greater in developed than developing countries, while it was the other way round with mobile broadband. Also revealed is that the digital ecosystem has an impact on productivity, and that effective ICT regulation can be good for economic growth.

title: Methods for determining national long-term strategies for spectrum utilization
content:
In this issue

Long-term strategy is about a defining vision and mission to solve key issues related to spectrum management for spectrum utilization, which will be implemented over ten years.

If spectrum resources are to adequately support national goals and objectives, long-term planning is essential. It can provide a basis for effective spectrum management to ensure that spectrum is efficiently allocated and assigned, to accommodate constantly evolving spectrum requirements by new systems and their applications. It also facilitates decision-making by providing a basis for the practical consideration and evaluation of alternative courses of action.

title: Economic contribution of broadband, digitization and ICT regulation: Econometric modelling for Africa
content:
In this issue

In 2018, ITU published a report on the global economic contribution of broadband, digitization and ICT regulation. Following the report, ITU received calls asking for a deeper analysis focused on specific regions of the world.

Economic Contribution of Broadband, Digitization and ICT Regulation: Econometric Modelling for Africa focuses on the Africa region. The report shows the economic impact of fixed and mobile broadband across the African continent, and it also shows the impact of digitization and the impact of a policy and regulatory framework on digitization in Africa. Specifically, the report – which begins with a summary of the global study – identifies which technologies should become a part of policy and how to ensure that the policies that are deployed stimulate the development of the digital ecosystem in Africa.

title: Implementation considerations for the introduction and transition to digital terrestrial sound and multimedia broadcasting
content:
In this issue

This Report highlights the benefits of digital sound broadcasting and presents some successful implementations. It also seeks to address some of the negative comments made during public consultations regarding ceasing analogue sound broadcasting, as well as technical and economic factors involved in bringing the advantages of digital sound broadcasting to all listeners around the world.

title: Implementing ITU-T International Standards to Shape Smart Sustainable Cities: The Case of Moscow
content:
In this issue

It is nine years since Moscow began its transition to becoming a smart city, with features such as an extensive Wi-Fi network, an intelligent traffic-control system and AI-based healthcare. ITU-T International Standards to Shape Smart Sustainable Cities: The Case of Moscow looks at Moscow’s initiative and studies the impact on its economy, society, public transport, environment and connectivity.

title: Technical realisation of signing in digital television
content:
In this issue

This Report describes practical solutions for closed signing in regular TV programmes, which include the provision of two video signals, one with and one without the signer or alternatively the transmission of the signer video as additional stream.

Described techniques allow the viewer to select between the TV programme with or without the inserted sign-language interpreter. The TV programme with the inserted signer is transmitted either in the broadcast multiplex or offered via the broadband Internet.

title: Be He@lthy Be Mobile – A Handbook on How to Implement MTB-Tobacco
content:
In this issue

Tuberculosis (TB) health-care providers involved in the World Heath Organization (WHO) and International Telecommunication Union (ITU) Be He@lthy, Be Mobile initiative can learn to implement a successful mTB- Tobacco programme. Be He@lthy Be Mobile – A Handbook on How to Implement MTB-Tobacco is an extensive and comprehensive guide to implementing a successful SMS texting campaign that impacts real behavioral change in tobacco users struggling with TB. The handbook gives detailed instruction on operations management, content development and adaptation, promotion and recruitment, technology specifications, and monitoring and evaluation. Working toward the end goal of changing harmful behaviors, TB health-care providers will learn how to use SMS messaging to supplement the routine TB care they are already providing.

title: The use of the terrestrial component of International Mobile Telecommunications (IMT) for Narrowband and Broadband Machine-Type Communications
content:
In this issue

Machine-type communications (MTC)  have entered our daily lives and offer the potential to help enable a more convenient and intelligent experience in a hyper-connected world. The deployment of MTC infrastructure networks is expanding rapidly. These networks are being deployed to support consumer, industrial and government applications with a variety of services. Globally, the importance of developing reliable and cost effective MTC solutions for various industries is increasing on a daily basis. Examples of these solutions include smart energy management, agriculture, water management, waste management, health, transportation and utilities that may have a direct impact on social and economic development.

This Report addresses the technical and operational aspects of terrestrial IMT-based radio networks and systems supporting MTC applications, as well as spectrum needed.

title: Technical studies on the satellite component of the VHF data exchange system
content:
In this issue

WRC-19 was invited to consider modifications of the Radio Regulations (RR) to enable a new VHF data exchange satellite component (call VDE-SAT).

This Report provides a summary of why a VDE-SAT component is required, identifies the spectrum requirements, and gives a technical description of the VDE-SAT and the results of the appropriate sharing and compatibility studies.

title: Guidance for operational practices in HDR television production
content:
In this issue

These operational practices are intended to provide initial guidance to help ensure optimum and consistent use of high dynamic range in television production using the Perceptual Quantization (PQ) and Hybrid Log-Gamma (HLG) methods specified in Recommendation ITU-R BT.2100. They should be read in conjunction with Report ITU-R BT.2390, which provides additional background information.

title: Description of interference into a digital terrestrial television receiver
content:
In this issue

Interference into a digital terrestrial television (DTT) receiver, i.e. violation of the protection ratio (PR), can impact the received picture.

This report describes the effects that limit the ability of DTT receivers from demodulating the wanted signal correctly. It also describes how, as digital broadcasting systems transmit source coded data, the relationship between demodulation failure and the visible picture impact is not as straightforward as it was in the case of analogue television. Finally, the results of measurements for a specific interference case that illustrate its impact on the received picture can be found in the Annexes.

title: Integrated broadcast-broadband systems
content:
In this issue

In a media scenario where convergent TV receivers are able to handle not only the broadcast signal but also applications delivered by broadband IP telecommunication services, there are opportunities to drive user engagement and to maximize the end-user’s satisfaction by offering a range of new
services. A system which enables to offer such services is called Integrated broadcast-broadband (IBB) system.

Part 1 of this report provides an overview of IBB systems and Part 2 offers general considerations to build IBB services.

title: Calculation model for SFN reception and reference receiver characteristics of ISDB-T system
content:
In this issue

This Report provides detailed considerations on receiver characteristics under single frequency network (SFN) conditions for ISDB-T system. It introduces new technical parameters that dominate receiver performances, in addition to the conventional planning parameters. It also t gives a reference receiver characteristic that would be applied in frequency planning and/or network design of ISDB-T based broadcasting systems.

title: Emerging usage of the terrestrial component of International Mobile Telecommunication (IMT)
content:
In this issue

This Report is a compilation document on existing and new usage of International Mobile Telecommunication (IMT) in specific applications. Further, it introduces potential new emerging applications of IMT in areas beyond traditional voice, data and entertainment type communications.

title: Planning parameters for terrestrial digital sound broadcasting systems in VHF bands
content:
In this issue

This Report provides planning parameters for the following digital terrestrial broadcasting systems: system C (also known as HD Radio), system G (also known as DRM+), system A (also known as DAB) and RAVIS system in VHF Bands. It also defines a framework for calculating all relevant network planning parameters that are very similar for the systems.

title: Collection of the Basic Texts of the International Telecommunication Union adopted by the 2018 Plenipotentiary Conference
content:
In this issue

A reference document containing: a) the Constitution and the Convention as amended by plenipotentiary conferences; b) General Rules of Conferences, Assemblies and Meetings of the Union; c) the full text of the Optional Protocol on the compulsory settlement of disputes relating to the Constitution, the Convention and the Administrative Regulations; d) the full text of all decisions, resolutions and recommendations in force; e) a list of abrogated decisions, resolutions and recommendations.

title: The global aeronautical distress and safety system
content:
In this issue

This Report provides consideration on the concept of operations on global aeronautical distress and safety system as defined in version 6.0 and approved by Air Navigation Commission of International Civil Aviation Organization.

title: Final Acts of the Plenipotentiary Conference
content:
In this issue

Decisions, Resolutions and Recommendations abrogated, adopted or revised by the Plenipotentiary Conference (Dubai, 2018). The Constitution and the Convention have not been amended by the Plenipotentiary Conference (Dubai, 2018).

title: HDTV and UHDTV including HDR-TV test materials for assessment of picture quality
content:
In this issue

This Report contains lists of HDTV, UHDTV including HDR-TV test materials and related information for
assessment of picture quality of television systems.

title: Technical Specification D3.7 – Blockchain-based data management for supporting IoT and SC&C
content:
In this issue

This technical specification provides technical descriptions and specifications of the blockchain-based data management in IoT and SC&C application domains. The scope of this technical specification includes: requirements of blockchain-based data management; generic reference model of blockchain-based data management; common capabilities and procedures of blockchain-based data management and procedures of blockchain-based data management.

title: Technical Specification D3.3 – Framework to support data interoperability in IoT environments
content:
In this issue

This Technical Specification addresses a framework for data interoperability, including key requirements with respect to data interoperability in IoT environments and many important elements to fulfil these requirements.

title: Technical Specification D3.2 – SensorThings API – Sensing
content:
In this issue

The SensorThings API provides an open, geospatial-enabled and unified way to interconnect the Internet of Things devices, data, and applications over the Web. It is an open standard, meaning it is non-proprietary, platform-independent, and perpetual royalty-free.

Although it is a new standard, it builds on a rich set of proven-working and widely-adopted open standards, such as the Web protocols and the OGC Sensor Web Enablement (SWE) standards, including the ISO/OGC Observation and Measurement data model [OGC 10-004r3 and ISO 19156:2011]. That also means the sensorThings API is extensible and can be applied to not only simple but also complex use cases.

This report provides a standard way to manage and retrieve observations and metadata from heterogeneous IoT sensor systems. It follows the REST principles, the use of an efficient JSON encoding, the use of MQTT protocol, the use of the flexible OASIS OData protocol and URL conventions.

title: E-Agriculture in action: Blockchain for agriculture – Opportunities and Challenges
content:
In this issue

Since blockchain technology was invented, in 2008, its uses have grown from its originally intended case of crypto-currency to hundreds of other cases in a variety of business and government, private and public, sectors. One such sector is agriculture.

E-Agriculture in Action: Blockchain for Agriculture – Opportunities and Challenges is a book published by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations and the International Telecommunication Union. Its purpose is to demystify blockchain technology and present some ideas on how it can be used in agriculture. The report simplifies the technical infrastructure of blockchain technology, highlights the implementation risks within the agriculture sector, how it can benefit agricultural supply chains, how smallholder farmers can use it to manage financial and agricultural risk, and more. As the use cases for blockchain in agriculture continue to grow, all stakeholders from non-governmental organizations to farming cooperatives will be able to put it to use for the greater good.

title: Spectrum needs of high altitude platform stations (HAPS) broadband links operating in the fixed service
content:
In this issue

On the issue of facilitating access to broadband applications delivered by high altitude platform station (HAPS), this contribution addresses additional spectrum needs for gateway and fixed terminal links required for HAPS to provide broadband connectivity in the fixed service.

title: Sharing and compatibility studies of HAPS systems in the fixed service for the frequency band 6 440-6 520 MHz
content:
In this issue

This Report includes the sharing and compatibility studies of HAPS systems in the 6 440-6 520 MHz frequency range with services to which the band is allocated on a primary basis,
with EESS passive service and with Radio Astronomy.

title: Guidance on the regulatory framework for national spectrum management
content:
In this issue

Questions on spectrum regulatory framework are of particular importance at a time when the number of wireless applications is increasing and applications intended for the general public, like mobile communications, are becoming mass-market applications worldwide.

This Report includes a description of approaches to management of national spectrum management organizations, an extract from the Handbook on National Spectrum Management, Best practices for national spectrum management, and  Article VI on Domestic Regulation from the GATS.

title: Toolkit for safe listening devices and systems
content:
In this issue

In recent years, there has been a growing threat to hearing and risk of hearing loss among young adults and teenagers due to the common practice of listening to loud music over a prolonged period of time. Toolkit for Safe Listening Devices and Systems provides an evidence-based guide through a consultative process with experts in sound, audiology, acoustics, communication, and smartphone technology to develop global standards on safe listening devices and systems. It summarizes the World Health Organization’s global standards for government, industry and civil leaders with a stake in preventing hearing loss. It also outlines the steps to effective implementation of these global standards. Through education and sound partnerships that spread information on safe listening, the irreversible effects of hearing loss can be prevented before they become a reality.

title: Use cases and service scenarios of disaster information service using unmanned aerial vehicles
content:
In this issue

Drones could make a difference in disasters. The sensors used by unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are equipped with sensors that capture images on the ground, with the data then being transferred to computer systems and analyzed for disaster prediction, prevention or response to save lives and limit economic losses. Use Cases and Service Scenarios for Disaster Information Service Using Unmanned Aerial Vehicles is a guide to using UAVs to collect information for disaster management. It looks at the technology, sees how drones can pre-empt as well as respond to disasters, and shows how they could be applied in droughts, earthquakes, wildfires, floods, landslides and volcanic eruptions.

title: ITU Journal (ICT Discoveries) – The impact of artificial intelligence on communication networks and services 2018
content:
In this issue

Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) are new technologies making their mark on many legacy institutions and traditional occupations, and that includes communications networks. In 2018, ITU launched ITU Journal: ICT Discoveries. The first issue of the journal, The Impact of Artificial Intelligence on Communication Networks and Services, delves into the many ways AI and ML influence the business, law, and ethics of ITU’s technical work. Collaborating with members of academia, ITU collected articles and insights from AI and ML experts as well as telecommunications professionals to explore the technical and social aspects of the intersection between these nascent technologies and communications networks.

title: FG ML5G – Unified architecture for machine learning in 5G and future networks
content:
In this issue

This document defines a unified architecture for Machine Learning in Fifth Generation and future networks. A comprehensive set of architectural requirements is presented, which leads to specific architecture constructs needed to satisfy these requirements. Based on these constructs, a logical ML pipeline (along with the requirements derived and its realizations in various types of architectures) is discussed. Finally, key architectural issues facing the integration of such an ML pipeline into continuously evolving future networks are also listed.

title: Resolutions and Decisions of the Council of the International Telecommunication Union 2018
content:
In this issue

This publication contains the complete text of the Council’s Resolutions and Decisions. it also contains three appendices (numerical list of all Resolutions adopted by the Council since its creation, numerical list of all Decisions adopted by the Council since its creation and an analytical table).

title: Technical and operational aspects of low-power wide-area networks for machine-type communication and the Internet of Things in frequency ranges harmonised for SRD operation
content:
In this issue

A new type of wireless system has been developed under the generic name of Low-Power Wide-Area Network (LPWAN) that may operate under the regulations for short range devices (SRD).

These new systems can help to address the challenges raised by the wide-ranging applications under development, where numerous devices need only to transmit a few messages per day. This Report provides details on the applications targeted by LPWAN, such as those related to smart cities, manufacturing, home automation, environment and agriculture, transport and logistics, energy and utilities.

title: Television colorimetry elements
content:
In this issue

This Report covers a wide range of topics including ideal colorimetry and future predictions, and some conclusions. It should be noted that over a period of time these predictions and conclusions may have been overtaken by the passage of time, or other industry factors. Reference is also made to an ideal camera, in this context a virtual camera.

title: NT software upgrade for one image
content:
In this issue

The NT system is not always capable of supporting two software images. In those cases, there is a modified procedure where NT can store one. NT Software Upgrade for One Image is a technical report that details the process and technology for this procedure. It includes information on software image management processing, OAM data for software management, message sets, and an overview of software upgrades. Complete with diagrammes, the technical report shows users how to upgrade their NT software.

title: Sharing between the radio astronomy service and active services in the frequency range 275-3 000 GHz
content:
In this issue

Certain characteristics of the frequency range 275-3 000 GHz combine to reduce the likelihood of interference between the radio astronomy service and active services in this range. This Report includes an introduction to those characteristics and how they affect potential sharing scenarios, as well as an analysis of interference to radio telescopes from co-frequency terrestrial and airborne transmitters.

title: The State of Broadband 2018: Broadband catalyzing sustainable development
content:
In this issue

The importance of broadband Internet for sustainable development is clear, as our societies continue to grow and develop. Broadband infrastructure is now vital infrastructure, as essential as water and electricity networks, but it is also becoming more invisible and integrated in utility networks in ‘smart’ infrastructure.

This report emphasizes the importance of investing in broadband to ensure the digital divide does not widen further.  It also reviews the implications of big data and Artificial Intelligence (AI) for development in education, health and our natural environment.  Finally, it concludes with a number of recommendations in different areas designed to advance progress in broadband at the national and international level in a coherent approach.

title: Smart Sustainable Development Model (SSDM)
content:
In this issue

How can you improve the world’s response to natural disasters? What is the best way to get funding to these countries? How can you set up a network of volunteers? Smart Sustainable Development Model Initiative: Tools for Rapid Emergency Responses and Sustainable Development, part of the ITU’s SSDM Initiative, shows how ICT can play a vital role in the relief effort.

The report provides an overview of proposals that grew out of three ITU working groups: a Global Emergency Fund for Rapid Response, bringing together donors and volunteers on the ground; a Volunteer Emergency Network, with ICT enabling first responders to share vital information, so that the disaster management is coordinated; and an SSDM Regulatory Toolkit and Guidelines to find a way round regulatory barriers in some countries to the use of ICT. A broad spectrum of interlinked issues is addressed, including how to harness ICT’s potential in socio-economic development, linking rural telecommunications and ICT development, and creating ecosystems where investments in telecom infrastructure are also used for disaster management.

title: Technical studies for establishing in-band power limits for earth stations operating in the frequency ranges 399.9-400.05 MHz and 401-403 MHz within the MSS, ESS and MetSat services
content:
In this issue

This Report contains the technical characteristics and results of current ITU-R studies for in-band power limits applicable to the Earth stations in the MSS in the frequency band 399.9-400.05 MHz and the MetSat and the EESS in the frequency band 401-403 MHz.

title: ITU Journal (ICT Discoveries)  – Data for Good 2018
content:
In this issue

The second issue of ITU Journal: ICT Discoveries, titled “Data for Good” features original research on the data dimensions of ICT-rich modern economies. Using information and insights drawn from the many ICT disciplines at work toward the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals, editors and authors analyze automation, smart city data in public services, data compression in multimedia services, cloud computing systems, connected machinery, and data protection and security in ICT to demonstrate the broad applications of data in the industry. Topics explored include using data to fuel autonomous, human-centric ICTs, the data dimensions of blockchain technology, network traffic-pattern prediction, aviation safety, smart sustainable cities, environmental resilience, healthcare and artificial intelligence, and the growing importance of data relevance to business, governance, policy, law, and consumer protection.

title: Maximising availability of international connectivity in the Pacific
content:
In this issue

The international connectivity of small island developing states is vital to economic development. In the Asia-Pacific region, universal broadband connectivity would draw together the Pacific islands and allow them to participate more fully in the global economy. While Pacific island connectivity has improved since 2007, a focus on policy and regulatory frameworks, building more cables, universal access to ICT and the adoption of telecommunication applications could have a big impact socially and economically. Maximizing Availability of International Connectivity in the Pacific provides an overview of connectivity among the Pacific islands, showcases case studies in several of them —  notably, Fiji, Papua New Guinea, Samoa, Tonga and Vanuatu — and provides recommendations for improving connectivity.

title: Technical criteria used for DTT planning in Central American and Caribbean Region
content:
In this issue

This Report is a contribution to the effort of  facilitating the processes of transition from Analogue to Digital Television (DTT) and allocation of the Digital Dividend. It presents a compilation of technical parameters and criteria to be used for digital television planning using the propagation method described in Recommendation ITU-R P.1546-5 in force, and taking into account the use of different television standards and different system combinations for the wanted and unwanted signals.

title: Setting the scene for 5G: opportunities and challenges
content:
In this issue

Bold promises have been made for the impact of 5G technology on the future of network communications: improved user experience, new applications, new business models and services, and improved network performance and reliability. On top of that, the technology is expected to bring huge economic gains. However, to realize these benefits will require significant levels of investment.

Setting the Scene for 5G: Opportunities and Challenges explores the dangers of 5G technology creating a digital divide between urban and rural areas around the world, the challenges for the public and private sectors, critical issues for policy-makers, how emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence can affect 5G development, and what kind of investments are necessary to propel the technology forward. Finally, the report makes recommendations for policy-makers designed to reduce the costs and simplify the processes of 5G implementation.

title: Loudness in Internet delivery of broadcast originated soundtracks
content:
In this issue

Note – This Report has been published only in English

title: Transport network support of IMT-2020/5G (October 2018)
content:
In this issue

Mobile traffic directed onto transport networks has specific requirements in support of IMT-200/5G networks. Transport Network Support of IMT-2020/5G (October 2018) outlines those requirements with reference to 5G wireless architecture, the synchronization distribution architecture, interfaces, management and control, multi-service support, and the support of 5G slicing in the transport network. The report addresses the evolution of wireless transport architecture from 4G to 5G, synchronization requirements, and capacity, latency and network-reach requirements. Additionally, the report offers a set of deployment scenarios for those making the transition to 5G wireless architecture.

title: Kaleidoscope 2018 – Machine learning for a 5G future
content:
In this issue

In November 2018, ITU held its 10th annual academic conference titled “Machine Learning for a 5G Future.” Out of that conference emerged a dialogue between academics and standardization experts in machine learning in the communications networking industry.

The result is this report covering the impact of machine learning (ML) in 5G planning and deployment, ML in telecommunication networks, artificial intelligence, data management optimization, network applications of ML, and the social, legal and ethical aspects of ML. Fifty-seven authors share their insights on these topics, explore development methodologies for next-generation wireless ecosystems that use ML and big data, review ML applications for improving critical resource management decisions in 5G and cloud computing, how ML will affect employment, and more. Authors come from academia, government, and industry from around the world.

title: Digital Identity Roadmap Guide
content:
In this issue

Identity is a crucial element for individuals and organizations. A digital identity allows each person or entity a means of establishing a distinguishable digital presence. It also enables social inclusion, digital transformation, and improved government and private services.

Digital Identity Roadmap Guide is a guide for policy-makers and other leaders to help them assess national policy and develop and manage a National Digital Identity Framework. It provides principles for a National Digital Identity Framework, key focus areas to consider when developing such a framework, and guidelines for creating a framework. It also identifies critical success factors and conflicting principles that can enhance the success of National Digital Identity Framework development and includes case studies of countries who have already created such a framework.

The guide is useful for government leaders as well as private sector leaders with an interest in digital identity.

title: Regulatory approaches to securing consumer privacy, trust and security
content:
In this issue

Can we trust the technology that offers unprecedented potential for social and economic development? At the end of 2017, there were over 4.2 billion active mobile broadband subscriptions and more than 3.5 billion people online around the world. Mobile technologies generated 5.4 per cent of GDP in the Asia-Pacific region. Active use of mobile technologies is growing year-on-year as network quality continues to improve. But despite the technological advances and the growth in take-up, consumer privacy and security are still major barriers to the digital economy.

Powering the Digital Economy: Regulatory Approaches to Securing Consumer Privacy, Trust and Security explores the growing importance and power of the digital economy — with the app market forecast to be worth USD 6.3 trillion a year by 2021 — but also the threat that it poses to data security.

The report analyses the impact of regulations and looks at countries that have rolled out national digital identity programmes.

title: Economic aspects of spectrum management
content:
In this issue

This Technical Report describes the different economic approaches for spectrum management activities based on new experiences of administrations, including on spectrum auctions and calculations of spectrum/licence fees. It also includes factors to be taken into account in an international comparison of fee levels, as well as guidelines on methodologies for the establishment of spectrum fees formula and system.

title:
Studies related to proposed change in 460-470 MHz secondary allocation for METSAT (space-to-Earth) to primary and addition of primary allocation to EESS 
(space-to-Earth)
content:
In this issue

This Report provides results of studies evaluating the potential for radio frequency interference from spacecraft operating in the MetSat (space-to-Earth) service and EESS (space-to-Earth) using the 460-470 MHz frequency band to incumbent systems in primary allocated services. Adjacent bands are similarly evaluated. Moreover, it also determines relevant pfd masks from the EESS and MetSat spacecraft required to protect incumbent systems based on static and/or dynamic analyses.

title: Digital identity in the ICT ecosystem: An overview
content:
In this issue

With almost half the world’s population online, digital identity is more important now than ever. The number of ways for consumers to have their identity compromised has outpaced our ability to protect it. Online purchases, digital payments, loans, government services such as passports and identification cards, tax returns, voting records, health and medical records, and social programmes are just a few of the ways people create online accounts that can be compromised. Digital Identity in the ICT Ecosystem: An Overview presents an overview of the challenges and opportunities involved in securing digital identities that cannot be compromised. It details a plan for the one billion connected people worldwide to establish a digital identity and how governments can protect that identity so that the world’s citizens can trust the technology they use every day in a number of ways.

title: Parameters needed for the registration of distributed radio astronomy systems
content:
In this issue

This Report addresses the question of whether the characteristics currently required by the ITU-R for notification of a radio astronomy station are sufficient to adequately describe the new generation of large distributed radio astronomy systems currently coming into operation or under construction.

title: Studies to accommodate spectrum requirements in the space operation service for non-geostationary satellites with short duration missions
content:
In this issue

This Report studies the spectrum requirements for telemetry, tracking and command in the space operations service for non-geostationary satellites (NGSO) satellites with short duration missions.

title: Technical characteristics for telemetry, tracking and command in the space operation service below 1 GHz for non-GSO satellites with short duration
content:
In this issue

This Report provides typical characteristics for telemetry, tracking and command in the space operation service below 1 GHz for NGSO satellite networks with short duration missions. Besides orbital parameters, the typical RF parameters in VHF and UHF are summarized for the space-to-Earth and the Earth-to-space directions. In addition, information on unwanted emissions is provided in order to aid sharing and compatibility studies.

title: Handbook for the development of a policy framework on ICT/e-Waste
content:
In this issue

Across the world, electrical and electronic devices are being bought but also discarded in record numbers, and this is a problem in developing countries that lack the techniques and infrastructure to safeguard the environment from the impact of hazardous waste. Handbook for the Development of a Policy Framework on ICT/e-Waste is a guide for policy-makers and government leaders, especially in developing countries, to help them devise effective e-Waste strategies. Centred on the three key areas of sustainable development, green ICT and the circular economy where valuable resources are constantly reused, it covers the importance of e-Waste regulations and describes how to design and implement an efficient waste-management system. It then reviews some of the most comprehensive standards for the recycling of electrical waste, and then provides a set of recommendations for the key points to be included in a regulatory framework for managing ICT waste.

title: ICT for Energy – Telecommunications and energy working for sustainable development
content:
In this issue

Smart grids, pay-as-you-go schemes and giving consumers enough information to reduce consumption … these are a few of the ways in which ICT can help the world meet the United Nations’ SDG 7 goals for sustainable development: universal access to affordable and reliable energy services; substantially greater use of renewables; and double the global rate of improvement in energy efficiency — all by 2030. With the UN needing to enhance international cooperation and expand the global infrastructure as it upgrades critical technology, ICT for Energy — Telecommunications and Energy Working for Sustainable Development discusses the role of ICT in hitting the SDG 7 targets. The report investigates the current business and regulatory incentives for cooperation between telecommunication and energy providers, looks at the European Union experience of collaboration between the two sectors, and sets out the requirements for further, successful partnerships.

title: The Future of Cable TV : Trends and Implications
content:
In this issue

Cable TV deserves a new definition. No longer confined to straightforward television services, it now encompasses services such as video-on-demand, internet access, cloud storage, and Internet-of-Things applications such as smart metering at home. These changes have been carried along on a wave of innovation and ICT convergence, and the waves continue to break. In The Future of Cable TV: Trends and Implications, the ITU provides an overview of the improvements needed in cables to deliver connected TV, and developments on which cable TV operators can capitalise, such as virtual reality, multi-service and multi-platform TV, and ultra-high-definition TV. There will also, however, be regulatory changes in setting new parameters for a changing industry. The future of cable TV will look vastly different to its past.

title: Assessing the Economic Impact of Artificial Intelligence
content:
In this issue

This is the first paper in a new series of ITU’s Issue Paper on Emerging Trends, which aims to identify and recognize emerging trends in the telecommunication/ICTs environment, and share the information with all ITU membership to enhance our capacity to understand the force transforming our society with the development of telecommunication/ICT.

Contributed by the McKinsey Global Institute, the economic and business research arm of
McKinsey & Company, it offers a framework for thinking about how to model the economic
impact of AI, putting this exercise in the context of the research on the dynamically changing world
of work in the light of automation, the need for a skills revolution, and the increasing and potential
use of AI by companies.

title: Compliance of audio-based navigation system for persons with vision impairment
content:
In this issue

Audio-based network navigation systems are designed for the visually impaired to help them explore their environment — providing guidance, for example, on walking surfaces, stairs and lifts — and overcome the obstacles posed by poor eyesight. Compliance of Audio-Based Navigation System for Persons with Vision Impairment is a technical report that addresses why these systems must comply with ITU recommendations. It offers critical measures for qualitative and empirical data, a protocol for allowing installers of audio-based navigation systems to assess their compliance, and a methodology for collecting data to ensure they continue to conform. The report also covers the components of audio instruction, among them specific features, landmarks and objects, and mobile applications.

title: Unwanted emissions of digital radio systems
content:
In this issue

In this Report, measurements of the unwanted emissions of a number of equipment samples of digital radio systems are presented and compared with: 1) the OoB emissions limits in Recommendation ITU-R SM.1541, regional agreements, and/or publications of Standards Development Organisations (SDOs); 2) the spurious emissions limits in Recommendation ITU-R SM.329, ERC/REC 74-01, and/or publications of Standards Development Organisations (SDOs).

The boundaries of the modulation-based unwanted emissions in these measurements are compared with the limits for the boundary between the out-of-band (OoB) and spurious domains from ITU-R publications.

title: M-Powering Development Initiative
content:
In this issue

Mobile technology and communications are opening up new opportunities for developing countries. The lives of millions of people — especially women, the poor and those living in remote areas — are being transformed. Entire economies are being redesigned to match the technological progress. But progress has not been fast enough — too many people are still waiting too long. m-Powering Development Initiative: Turning Opportunities into Reality explores how the opportunities can best be harnessed for further economic and social development. Drawing on examples of inspiring projects and initiatives, the report sets out to show how everyone can benefit if the right technologies are identified, regulatory and technical barriers broken down and incentives put in place for connectivity and uptake. It illustrates the importance of the opportunities and asks who can help transform them into reality.

title: Guide to developing a national cybersecurity strategy – Strategic engagement in cybersecurity
content:
In this issue

In the past two decades, a global digital revolution has transformed societies and cultures, benefiting billions of people. However, while the Internet has become central to realising economic and social opportunities, cyberthreats are also evolving rapidly and compromising trust in ICT –  and only 76 countries have a clear plan in place to address that.

Guide to Developing a National Cybersecurity Strategy — Strategic Engagement in Cybersecurity draws on the experiences and knowledge of 12 contributors from the public and private sectors to set out how to identify a common approach to risk management, establish response capabilities and contingency plans, promote information-sharing, conduct cybersecurity exercises, and encourage skills development. The guide looks at the overarching principles of devising a cybersecurity strategy, from human rights to best practices, and can assist policy-makers in developing offensive and defensive cybersecurity capabilities that protect our assets against illegal and destructive activities in cyberspace.

tag: SDG 8 Decent Work and Economic Growth
title: Capacity building in a changing ICT environment
content:
In this issue

The last two decades have seen increased global availability of fixed and/or mobile broadband access. Along with greater connectivity, information accessibility has grown, opportunities for communication and collaboration have proliferated, and economic and social circumstances have improved for much of the world.

Capacity Building in a Changing ICT Environment shows how online education and e-learning are integral to harnessing the power of digital transformation.  The report covers specific required digital skillsets for delivery of digital education services, capacity building for Internet of Things, digital pathways for distance learning, smart learning, teaching in the digital era, emerging trends and technologies in ICT, lessons learned in IoT capacity building in developing nations, building online adjunct faculty capacity, and emerging practices in smart learning across diverse cultural communities.

This comprehensive report helps stakeholders contextualize education in the 21st century.
